description: Essential programming languages, paradigms, and best practices

topics.title: Python Fundamentals

definition.text: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and versatility. It supports multiple programming paradigms including procedural, object-oriented, and functional programming. Python emphasizes code readability with significant whitespace.

keyFormulas.name: Built-in Types
keyFormulas.formula: int, float, str, bool, list, dict, set, tuple

examples.question: Create a function that filters even numbers from a list

steps.result: [n for n in numbers if n % 2 == 0]
return [n for n in numbers if n % 2 == 0]

examples.finalAnswer: def filter_even(numbers): return [n for n in numbers if n % 2 == 0]

realWorldApplications.title: Web Development
realWorldApplications.description: Django and Flask power many web applications

realWorldApplications.title: Data Science
realWorldApplications.description: Pandas, NumPy, and scikit-learn for data analysis

codeExample.python:
# Variables and types
name = 'Python'  # str
version = 3.11   # float
is_awesome = True  # bool

# List comprehension
squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)]

# Dictionary
user = {'name': 'Alice', 'age': 25}

# Function with type hints
def greet(name: str) -> str:
    return f'Hello, {name}!'

tips: Use virtual environments (venv) for project isolation
Follow PEP 8 style guide for clean code
List comprehensions are more Pythonic than loops

topics.title: JavaScript Fundamentals

definition.text: JavaScript is a dynamic, interpreted programming language primarily used for web development. It enables interactive web pages and runs in all modern browsers. With Node.js, JavaScript also runs on servers.

keyFormulas.name: Variable Declarations
keyFormulas.meaning: Modern JS prefers const and let

examples.question: Fetch data from an API using async/await

realWorldApplications.title: Frontend Development
realWorldApplications.description: React, Vue, Angular power modern web UIs

tips: Use const by default, let when reassignment needed
Arrow functions don't have their own 'this'
Use optional chaining (?.) to avoid null errors

topics.title: TypeScript Essentials

definition.text: TypeScript is a typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript. It adds static type checking, interfaces, and other features that help catch errors at compile time rather than runtime.

examples.question: Create a typed function that fetches a user

steps.result: interface User { id: number; name: string; }

realWorldApplications.title: Large Codebases
realWorldApplications.description: Type safety reduces bugs in teams

tips: Start with strict mode enabled for best type checking
Use interfaces for objects, types for unions and primitives
Leverage type inference - don't over-annotate

topics.title: Object-Oriented Programming

definition.text: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which contain data (attributes) and code (methods). The four pillars are: Encapsulation (hiding internal state), Inheritance (reusing code), Polymorphism (same interface, different behavior), and Abstraction (simplifying complex reality).

examples.question: Demonstrate polymorphism with shapes

steps.action: Create abstract Shape class with area()

examples.finalAnswer: Each shape calculates area differently but all respond to the same area() method call

realWorldApplications.title: Game Development
realWorldApplications.description: Characters, items, and levels as objects

realWorldApplications.title: GUI Applications
realWorldApplications.description: Widgets and components as class hierarchies

tips: Favor composition over inheritance
Follow the Single Responsibility Principle
Use interfaces to define contracts

topics.title: Functional Programming

definition.text: Functional Programming (FP) is a paradigm that treats computation as evaluation of mathematical functions. It emphasizes immutability, pure functions (no side effects), and higher-order functions. FP leads to more predictable and testable code.

keyFormulas.name: FP Core Concepts
keyFormulas.formula: Pure Functions + Immutability + Higher-Order Functions = Functional Programming

examples.question: Transform a list of numbers using map, filter, reduce
examples.finalAnswer: Chain: numbers.filter(n => n % 2 === 0).map(n => n * 2).reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0)

realWorldApplications.title: Testing
realWorldApplications.description: Pure functions are easy to test

codeExample.python:
from functools import reduce

# Pure function - same input always gives same output
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

# Higher-order function - takes or returns function
def make_multiplier(factor):
    return lambda x: x * factor

double = make_multiplier(2)
print(double(5))  # 10

# Map, filter, reduce
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squares = list(map(lambda x: x**2, numbers))
evens = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, numbers))
total = reduce(lambda a, b: a + b, numbers)

tips: Pure functions are deterministic and have no side effects
Avoid mutating data - create new copies instead
Use map/filter/reduce instead of loops when appropriate

topics.title: Error Handling

definition.text: Error handling is the process of responding to and recovering from error conditions in programs. It involves anticipating potential failures, catching exceptions, and providing graceful degradation. Good error handling improves user experience and aids debugging.

keyFormulas.name: Try-Catch Pattern
keyFormulas.formula: try { risky code } catch (error) { handle error } finally { cleanup }

examples.question: Handle API errors gracefully
examples.finalAnswer: Layered error handling: network errors, HTTP errors, and parsing errors all handled appropriately

realWorldApplications.title: User Input
realWorldApplications.description: Validate and provide helpful error messages

tips: Catch specific exceptions, not generic Exception
Always log errors with context for debugging
Use custom error classes for domain-specific errors

topics.title: Clean Code Principles

definition.text: Clean code is code that is easy to read, understand, and maintain. It follows consistent conventions, expresses intent clearly, and avoids unnecessary complexity. Clean code principles help teams collaborate effectively and reduce technical debt.

keyFormulas.name: Clean Code Principles
keyFormulas.formula: DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) + KISS (Keep It Simple) + YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It)

examples.question: Refactor code with magic numbers
examples.finalAnswer: Named constants make code self-documenting and easier to maintain

realWorldApplications.title: Code Reviews
realWorldApplications.description: Clean code is easier to review

realWorldApplications.title: Team Collaboration
realWorldApplications.description: Others can understand and modify your code

codeExample.python:
# Bad: Magic numbers, unclear intent
def calc(d):
    return d * 86400

# Good: Meaningful names, clear intent
SECONDS_PER_DAY = 86400

def days_to_seconds(days: int) -> int:
    """Convert days to seconds."""
    return days * SECONDS_PER_DAY

# Bad: Long function doing many things
# Good: Small functions with single responsibility
def process_order(order):
    validate_order(order)
    amount = calculate_total(order)
    payment = process_payment(order, amount)
    send_confirmation(order, payment)

tips: Functions should do one thing and do it well
Use meaningful names that reveal intent
Keep functions short (< 20 lines is a good guideline)

topics.title: Testing Fundamentals

definition.text: Software testing is the process of evaluating code to ensure it works correctly. Unit tests verify individual functions, integration tests check component interactions, and end-to-end tests validate complete workflows. Testing increases confidence in code changes.

keyFormulas.name: Testing Pyramid
keyFormulas.formula: Many Unit Tests > Some Integration Tests > Few E2E Tests

examples.question: Write a unit test for an add function
examples.finalAnswer:
def test_add():
    assert add(2, 3) == 5
    assert add(-1, 1) == 0
    assert add(0, 0) == 0

tips: Write tests before or alongside code (TDD)
Test edge cases and error conditions
Keep tests independent and isolated

topics.title: Debugging Techniques

definition.text: Debugging is the process of finding and fixing bugs in software. It involves systematic approaches to isolate problems, understand root causes, and implement solutions. Good debugging skills significantly reduce development time.

examples.question: Debug a function that returns wrong results

steps.explanation: A reproducible bug is easier to fix

steps.result: Use binary search to find the failing line
steps.explanation: Eliminate half the code at each step

steps.action: Examine the state at failure point

steps.explanation: Ensure fix doesn't break other things

examples.finalAnswer: Systematic approach finds bugs faster than random guessing

codeExample.python:
import logging
import pdb

# Set up logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

def calculate_total(items):
    logger.debug(f'Processing {len(items)} items')
    
    total = 0
    for item in items:
        logger.debug(f'Item: {item}')
        # pdb.set_trace()  # Interactive debugger
        total += item['price'] * item['quantity']
    
    logger.info(f'Total calculated: {total}')
    return total

tips: Read error messages carefully - they often tell you exactly what's wrong
Use print/console.log strategically to trace program flow
Rubber duck debugging: explain the code to find the bug

topics.title: Regular Expressions

definition.text: Regular expressions (regex) are patterns used to match character combinations in strings. They are powerful tools for searching, validating, and manipulating text. While the syntax can be complex, mastering regex is invaluable for text processing.

examples.question: Validate an email address with regex

codeExample.python:
import re

# Match pattern
pattern = r'\d{3}-\d{3}-\d{4}'
text = 'Call me at 123-456-7890'
match = re.search(pattern, text)
if match:
    print(match.group())  # 123-456-7890

# Find all matches
emails = re.findall(r'[\w.+-]+@[\w-]+\.[\w.-]+', text)

# Replace
cleaned = re.sub(r'\s+', ' ', text)  # Multiple spaces to single

# Capture groups
pattern = r'(\w+)@(\w+\.\w+)'
match = re.match(pattern, 'user@example.com')
print(match.groups())  # ('user', 'example.com')

tips: Test regex patterns at regex101.com with explanations
Use raw strings (r'pattern') in Python to avoid escape issues
Start simple and build up complexity gradually

topics.title: API Design Principles

definition.text: API (Application Programming Interface) design is the practice of creating interfaces that allow software components to communicate. Good API design focuses on usability, consistency, and clarity. RESTful APIs follow HTTP conventions while GraphQL provides flexible queries.

keyFormulas.name: REST HTTP Methods
keyFormulas.meaning: Standard HTTP methods for CRUD operations

examples.question: Design RESTful endpoints for a users resource
examples.finalAnswer: RESTful URLs use nouns (resources) and HTTP methods (verbs) for actions

tips: Use plural nouns for resources: /users not /user
Version your API: /api/v1/users
Return appropriate HTTP status codes

topics.title: Data Structures in Practice

definition.text: Understanding when to use which data structure is crucial for writing efficient code. Lists/arrays for ordered data, sets for unique values, dictionaries/maps for key-value lookups, and queues/stacks for FIFO/LIFO operations.

keyFormulas.name: Choosing Data Structures
keyFormulas.formula: Lookup by key ‚Üí Dict/Map | Ordered unique ‚Üí Set | Ordered ‚Üí List | LIFO ‚Üí Stack | FIFO ‚Üí Queue
keyFormulas.meaning: Match data structure to access pattern

examples.question: Choose the right data structure for a word frequency counter

steps.action: Need to map words to counts

examples.finalAnswer: Use Counter or defaultdict for word frequency counting

realWorldApplications.title: Caching
realWorldApplications.description: LRU cache uses dict + doubly linked list

codeExample.python:
from collections import Counter, defaultdict, deque

# Word frequency
words = ['apple', 'banana', 'apple', 'cherry']
freq = Counter(words)  # {'apple': 2, 'banana': 1, 'cherry': 1}

# Group items by key
users = [{'name': 'Alice', 'dept': 'Eng'}, {'name': 'Bob', 'dept': 'Eng'}]
by_dept = defaultdict(list)
for user in users:
    by_dept[user['dept']].append(user['name'])

# Queue for BFS
queue = deque([start_node])
while queue:
    node = queue.popleft()  # O(1) unlike list.pop(0)
    queue.append(next_node)

tips: Profile before optimizing - use the right tool
Sets are great for membership testing: O(1)
Use deque for queue operations in Python

topics.title: Asynchronous Programming

definition.text: Asynchronous programming allows code to perform non-blocking operations, enabling other code to run while waiting for I/O operations like network requests or file reads. Async/await syntax makes async code look synchronous while maintaining non-blocking behavior.

examples.question: Fetch multiple URLs concurrently
examples.finalAnswer: Promise.all enables concurrent async operations, much faster than sequential

codeExample.python:
import asyncio
import aiohttp

async def fetch_url(session, url):
    async with session.get(url) as response:
        return await response.json()

async def fetch_all(urls):
    async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
        tasks = [fetch_url(session, url) for url in urls]
        results = await asyncio.gather(*tasks)
        return results

# Run
urls = ['url1', 'url2', 'url3']
results = asyncio.run(fetch_all(urls))

tips: Use Promise.all for concurrent operations
Use Promise.allSettled when some failures are acceptable
Don't forget to handle errors in async code

topics.title: Code Review Best Practices

definition.text: Code review is the systematic examination of source code by peers. It catches bugs, improves code quality, spreads knowledge across the team, and ensures consistent coding standards. Effective reviews are constructive, focused, and timely.

keyFormulas.name: Review Focus Areas
keyFormulas.meaning: What to look for in code reviews

examples.question: What makes effective code review feedback?

steps.result: Point to exact lines with issues

examples.finalAnswer: Good feedback is specific, educational, and actionable

codeExample.python:
# Before: Hard to understand
def f(l):
    return [x for x in l if x > 0 and x % 2 == 0]

# After: Clear naming and documentation
def filter_positive_even_numbers(numbers: list[int]) -> list[int]:
    """Return positive even numbers from the input list."""
    return [
        num for num in numbers 
        if num > 0 and num % 2 == 0
    ]

# Code review comment:
# Good use of type hints! Consider adding input validation
# for edge cases (empty list, None input).

tips: Review small PRs frequently rather than large ones rarely
Use automated tools (linters, formatters) for style issues
Keep reviews constructive and assume good intent

topics.title: Git Workflow Strategies

definition.text: Git workflows define how teams collaborate using version control. Popular strategies include GitFlow (feature branches, develop, main), GitHub Flow (simpler, main + feature branches), and Trunk-Based Development (frequent merges to main). Choose based on team size and release cadence.

examples.question: Implement GitHub Flow for a feature
examples.finalAnswer: GitHub Flow: branch ‚Üí commit ‚Üí PR ‚Üí review ‚Üí merge

codeExample.bash:
# GitHub Flow
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b feature/new-feature

# Make changes and commit
git add .
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature"

# Push and create PR
git push -u origin feature/new-feature
# Open PR on GitHub/GitLab

# After approval
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git merge --squash feature/new-feature
git push origin main
git branch -d feature/new-feature

tips: Use conventional commits: feat:, fix:, docs:, etc.
Keep feature branches short-lived (< 1 week)
Rebase feature branches on main before merging

topics.title: Performance Optimization

definition.text: Performance optimization is improving code efficiency in terms of speed (time) and memory (space). It involves profiling to find bottlenecks, choosing efficient algorithms and data structures, and applying language-specific optimizations. Always measure before and after optimization.

keyFormulas.name: Optimization Rules
keyFormulas.formula: Measure ‚Üí Identify Bottleneck ‚Üí Optimize ‚Üí Measure Again

examples.question: Optimize a slow database query

steps.result: EXPLAIN ANALYZE shows full table scan

examples.finalAnswer: Indexing and caching are common database optimizations

realWorldApplications.title: Web Performance
realWorldApplications.description: Reduce load times, improve Core Web Vitals

codeExample.python:
import cProfile
import functools

# Profile code
cProfile.run('my_function()')

# Memoization for expensive computations
@functools.lru_cache(maxsize=128)
def expensive_calculation(n):
    # ... complex computation
    return result

# Use generators for memory efficiency
def process_large_file(filename):
    with open(filename) as f:
        for line in f:  # Lazy, doesn't load entire file
            yield process_line(line)

# Avoid repeated calculations
# Bad
for item in items:
    if item in expensive_filter(data):  # Called each iteration!
        ...

# Good
filtered = set(expensive_filter(data))  # Calculate once
for item in items:
    if item in filtered:  # O(1) lookup
        ...

tips: Don't optimize prematurely - measure first
Cache expensive operations
Use appropriate data structures for your access patterns
